pullRequest.body:
Prove that a nonarchimedean group is a totally disconnected topological space. 

Co-authored-by: Kevin Buzzard <k.buzzard@imperial.ac.uk>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2f3455fa89](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16687/commits/2f3455fa89f0c9b74ddf24b25a847fb6b80fc607)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Nonarchimedean.TotallyDisconnected`|993|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ exists_openSubgroup_separating`
`+ instance (priority := 100) instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

I only just noticed this PR. It seems several of us (you, me, @pechersky, and possibly more) are thinking along the same lines. To be precise,

- Yakov showed in #17297 (merged) that metric spaces with an ultrametric are totally disco,
- I show in #17262 (awaiting review) that _commutative_ normed groups with an ultrametric norm are nonarchimedean groups,
- you show here that nonarchimedean groups are totally disco.

It seems to me like none of these statements actually imply the other (with the definitions in force in mathlib); and I don't see any obvious way of formulating a more general statement that implies more than one of the above. Still I think it's probably worth us all reading each other's code, and thinking if there's anything in common in the proofs that could profitably be factored out. I'll take a look at your code here later today (I have a long train journey to occupy!)

Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack. 

I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

```
namespace NonarchimedeanGroup

variable {G : Type*} [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T1Space G]

@[to_additive] instance instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
  isTotallySeparated_univ x _ y _ hxy := by
    obtain âŸ¨V, hâŸ© := is_nonarchimedean _ (isOpen_ne.mem_nhds (Ne.symm (inv_mul_eq_one.not.mpr hxy)))
    refine âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul x, (V.isClosed.smul x).isOpen_compl, mem_own_leftCoset ..,
      ?_, (Set.union_compl_self _).ge, Set.disjoint_compl_right_iff_subset.mpr (le_refl _)âŸ©
    simpa only [Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff] using fun a â†¦ h a rfl

example : TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := inferInstance -- works

end NonarchimedeanGroup
```

> Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack.
> 
> I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

Any topological group is a regular space by [TopologicalGroup.regularSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#TopologicalGroup.regularSpace), so if it is a T0 space, then it is a T3 space. Therefore, as long as the version for `T2Space` is proven, the version for `T0Space` can be directly obtained via `inferInstance`.

````lean
local instance (G : Type*) [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T2Space G] :
    TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := sorry

instance (G : Type*) [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T0Space G] :
    TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := inferInstance
````

> > Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack.
> > I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

> Any topological group is a regular space by [TopologicalGroup.regularSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#TopologicalGroup.regularSpace), so if it is a T0 space, then it is a T3 space. 

Glad to hear we have this! What I actually wasn't sure about was whether `NonarchimedeanGroup` implied `TopologicalGroup` â€“ the definition makes perfect sense for a topological space that is also an abstract group; you don't need to assume continuity of the group operations to define it, although it does seem that mathlib has chosen to enforce that G be a topological group nonetheless. (Indeed I suspect that the nonarchimedean property very probably *implies* continuity of the group operations, which would mean two of the arguments to the constructor of `NonarchimedeanGroup` are redundant, but I haven't checked that carefully.)

> I only just noticed this PR. It seems several of us (you, me, @pechersky, and possibly more) are thinking along the same lines. To be precise,
> 
> * Yakov showed in [[Merged by Bors] - feat(MetricSpace/Ultra): `TotallyDisconnectedSpace X` when X is ultrametricÂ #17297](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17297) (merged) that metric spaces with an ultrametric are totally disco,
> * I show in [feat (Analysis/Normed/Group): ultrametric normed groups are nonarchimedeanÂ #17262](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17262) (awaiting review) that _commutative_ normed groups with an ultrametric norm are nonarchimedean groups,
> * you show here that nonarchimedean groups are totally disco.
> 
> It seems to me like none of these statements actually imply the other (with the definitions in force in mathlib); and I don't see any obvious way of formulating a more general statement that implies more than one of the above. Still I think it's probably worth us all reading each other's code, and thinking if there's anything in common in the proofs that could profitably be factored out. I'll take a look at your code here later today (I have a long train journey to occupy!)

Thanks very much for reviewing my code! I didn't know about the PRs #17297 and #17262. I wrote this PR and the one you previously reviewed in order to state things concerning representation theory of reductive p-adic groups. I had discussed with Yakov the fact that Mathlib is missing a definition of local fields (I was working around this). Do you have any thoughts about how all of our code might work together?
I tried to rename the file to TotallySeparated.lean, but this failed. How do I do this properly?

> I tried to rename the file to TotallySeparated.lean, but this failed. How do I do this properly?

You need to modify the file names in `Mathlib.lean` as well.
By the way, I think you can mention in the docstring that `TotallyDisconnectedSpace` is implied by `TotallySeparatedSpace`.

> Do you have any thoughts about how all of our code might work together?

I think "very nicely" is the answer :-) There doesn't seem to be any overlap between this and the other two PR's I mentioned, rather they combine together very well (unlike the case with Yakov's PR and mine where there was genuine duplication). It's interesting to hear that you are working towards smooth, admissible, etc reps of LCTD groups, so the "natural example" of G for you is probably GL(2, Qp). It's a beautiful theory, I'm sure you'll have a lot of fun with it. :smile:

As for this PR: I see that you've followed my suggestion to prove "totally separated", and let Lean's typeclass instance machinery deduce "totally disconnected" from that. It's clear that "totally disconnected" will get used more often though, so changing the filename is optional (but Yongle is totally right that the docstring needs updating). 

I did also suggest an alternative layout for the argument (cf comment starting "Thinking a little further about this..."), which shortens things slightly by not having the lemma  `exists_openSubgroup_separating` as a separate declaration, but instead folding it into the proof of the instance. I guess the question is: in your view, is `exists_openSubgroup_separating` only useful as a step towards the totally-separated instance, or might it have other uses beyond the current PR? If it's a one-trick pony, we should fold it into the proof of the instance rather than having a separate lemma. Conversely, if it has other uses, it should have a proper docstring. (Either way is fine with me.)

> Can you also show the more general result that all ultrametric spaces ([IsUltrametricDist](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Ultra/Basic.html#IsUltrametricDist)) is totally separated?

Maybe this relates to @loefflerd 's comment (above), regarding PRs  #17297 and #17262 'working together' with this one?
Sorry, I didn't look up the definition of NonarchimedeanGroup. The result I said is true but is irrelevant here.

> > Do you have any thoughts about how all of our code might work together?
> 
> I think "very nicely" is the answer :-) There doesn't seem to be any overlap between this and the other two PR's I mentioned, rather they combine together very well (unlike the case with Yakov's PR and mine where there was genuine duplication). It's interesting to hear that you are working towards smooth, admissible, etc reps of LCTD groups, so the "natural example" of G for you is probably GL(2, Qp). It's a beautiful theory, I'm sure you'll have a lot of fun with it. ðŸ˜„
> 
> As for this PR: I see that you've followed my suggestion to prove "totally separated", and let Lean's typeclass instance machinery deduce "totally disconnected" from that. It's clear that "totally disconnected" will get used more often though, so changing the filename is optional (but Yongle is totally right that the docstring needs updating).
> 
> I did also suggest an alternative layout for the argument (cf comment starting "Thinking a little further about this..."), which shortens things slightly by not having the lemma `exists_openSubgroup_separating` as a separate declaration, but instead folding it into the proof of the instance. I guess the question is: in your view, is `exists_openSubgroup_separating` only useful as a step towards the totally-separated instance, or might it have other uses beyond the current PR? If it's a one-trick pony, we should fold it into the proof of the instance rather than having a separate lemma. Conversely, if it has other uses, it should have a proper docstring. (Either way is fine with me.)

Yes! I'm working from Bernshtein and Zelevinskii. 

It seems like a good idea to keep the filename, for advertisement, if "totally disconnected" will be used more often. 

Also in response to Johan's comment, I am keeping the lemma separate, but putting it in the same namespace. Currently, I have no other uses for the lemma, but it seems potentially handy.

Looks good to me! Thanks for all your work on this, looking forward to the next PR.

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

> all ultrametric spaces (IsUltrametricDist) is totally separated

Opened #17427 for this

Thanks!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11391664103/job/31695943864)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11392629135/job/31699123252)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11392629135/job/31699123531)

I spent a while carefully reading this step-by-step as my train rolled through the Alps, and wrote a whole load of very detailed comments.

Ironically, as I was reviewing the very last declaration, I realised that the whole thing can be done a bit differently. The point is that `TotallyDisconnectedSpace` is implied by `TotallySeparatedSpace`, and `TotallySeparatedSpace` is actually **easier** to prove for nonarchimedean groups. So you can just do this straight after `open_subgroup_separating`:
```lean
@[to_additive]
instance instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
  isTotallySeparated_univ x _ y _ hxy := by
    rcases open_subgroup_separating (hxy âˆ˜ inv_mul_eq_one.mp) with âŸ¨A, V, hA, -, hAVâŸ©
    refine âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul x, (V.isClosed.smul x).isOpen_compl, mem_own_leftCoset ..,
        ?_, (Set.union_compl_self _).ge, Set.disjoint_compl_right_iff_subset.mpr (le_refl _)âŸ©
    rw [Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff]
    exact Set.disjoint_left.mp hAV hA
```
This means the other lemmas in this file aren't needed any more for the totally-disconnected proof. Do you have specific reasons for wanting the other lemmas from this file for other downstream PR's? In any case I've left my comments on them here in case you find the general style guidance there useful, even if the code itself doesn't end up getting merged.

~~Can you also show the more general result that all ultrametric spaces ([IsUltrametricDist](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Ultra/Basic.html#IsUltrametricDist)) is totally separated?~~

~~Sorry, I'm not sure this is correct.~~

Many variables in theorems should use implicit variables, as they can be derived from other variables. For example, in `open_subgroup_separating`, it should be `{G : Type*} {t : G}`, in `non_empty_intersection_compl_coset`, it should be `{G : Type*} {x y : G} {U : Set G} (hx : x âˆˆ U) {A : Opens G}`, in `non_empty_intersection_coset`, it should be `{G : Type*} {y : G} {U : Set G}`, and in `non_singleton_set_disconnected`, it should be `{G : Type*} {x y : G} {U : Set G}`.

I spent a while carefully reading this step-by-step as my train rolled through the Alps, and wrote a whole load of very detailed comments.

Ironically, as I was reviewing the very last declaration, I realised that the whole thing can be done a bit differently. The point is that `TotallyDisconnectedSpace` is implied by `TotallySeparatedSpace`, and `TotallySeparatedSpace` is actually **easier** to prove for nonarchimedean groups. So you can just do this straight after `open_subgroup_separating`:
```lean
@[to_additive]
instance instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
  isTotallySeparated_univ x _ y _ hxy := by
    rcases open_subgroup_separating (hxy âˆ˜ inv_mul_eq_one.mp) with âŸ¨A, V, hA, -, hAVâŸ©
    refine âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul x, (V.isClosed.smul x).isOpen_compl, mem_own_leftCoset ..,
        ?_, (Set.union_compl_self _).ge, Set.disjoint_compl_right_iff_subset.mpr (le_refl _)âŸ©
    rw [Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff]
    exact Set.disjoint_left.mp hAV hA
```
This means the other lemmas in this file aren't needed any more for the totally-disconnected proof. Do you have specific reasons for wanting the other lemmas from this file for other downstream PR's? In any case I've left my comments on them here in case you find the general style guidance there useful, even if the code itself doesn't end up getting merged.

~~Can you also show the more general result that all ultrametric spaces ([IsUltrametricDist](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Ultra/Basic.html#IsUltrametricDist)) is totally separated?~~

~~Sorry, I'm not sure this is correct.~~
I think this lemma is not necessary. You can use `Nonempty.subset_singleton_iff` directly.

```suggestion
    exact con <| (Set.Nonempty.subset_singleton_iff âŸ¨x, mem_connectedComponentâŸ©).mp con2
```
This lemma holds for general topological groups and should not be in the `NonarchimedeanGroup` namespace. It should be moved to the file for topological groups.
Same as `non_empty_intersection_compl_coset`, it should not be in the `NonarchimedeanGroup` namespace and should be moved to the file for topological groups.

To move these lemmas to the file for topological groups, should I just put them in a `TopologicalGroup` namespace? 

Thank you very much for reviewing my work!

> To move these lemmas to the file for topological groups, should I just put them in a `TopologicalGroup` namespace?
> 
> Thank you very much for reviewing my work!

Yes, they should be in the `TopologicalGroup` namespace. If you think this lemma won't be used in the future, you can also choose not to move it to the `TopologicalGroup` file and instead change it to a `private lemma`.

> > To move these lemmas to the file for topological groups, should I just put them in a `TopologicalGroup` namespace?
> > Thank you very much for reviewing my work!
> 
> Yes, they should be in the `TopologicalGroup` namespace. If you think this lemma won't be used in the future, you can also choose not to move it to the `TopologicalGroup` file and instead change it to a `private lemma`.

So do you want them to be `private lemma`? If so, you should change `lemma` to `private lemma`. If not, you should move them to the file on topological groups.
If I change them to private lemma, the `@[to_additive]` tag does not work. Do you have any suggestions?

> If I change them to private lemma, the `@[to_additive]` tag does not work. Do you have any suggestions?

This may be a bug: after setting it as a private lemma, `@[to_additive]` does not transform the Group in the namespace to AddGroup. This causes the lemma name to remain the same after the `@[to_additive]` operation, resulting in an error. I think you can remove the namespace and change the name to something like `non_empty_intersection_group_coset`.

If there is a bug in `@[to_additive]` then it should certainly be reported on Zulip. FWIW, you can explicitly give the name for the additivized lemma and the problem goes away:
```lean
@[to_additive TopologicalAddGroup.nonempty_intersection_coset]
private lemma nonempty_intersection_coset ...
```

```suggestion
lemma non_empty_intersection_coset (hy : y âˆˆ U)
```

```suggestion
    (hx : x âˆˆ U) (hy : y âˆˆ U) (hxy : y â‰  x) : Â¬ IsConnected U := by
```

```suggestion
variable {G : Type*} [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T2Space G]
```

```suggestion
      Disjoint (A : Set G) V :=
    open_subgroup_separating (((mul_right_injective yâ»Â¹).ne_iff' (inv_mul_cancel y)).mpr hxy.symm)
```

```suggestion
  simp [Disjoint.inter_eq dva] at mem
```

Completely cosmetic of course, but I would personally write the statement as
```suggestion
lemma open_subgroup_separating {t : G} (ht : t â‰  1) : 
    âˆƒ (A : Opens G) (V : OpenSubgroup G), t âˆˆ A âˆ§ 1 âˆˆ V âˆ§ Disjoint (A : Set G) V := by
```
There's no need to use "variable ... in" when you're introducing a new variable; it's only really needed when you're modifying the binders on an existing section variable. (This applies to many lemmas in the current PR.) It's also cleaner to put the line break in between the hypotheses and the conclusion. As for the name, maybe "exists_openSubgroup_separating" is slightly clearer? Since `OpenSubgroup` is already the name of a type in mathlib it shouldn't have an underscore. (Yes, the naming conventions are really arcane, sorry!)

I'm not sure why you have the `fun _ â†¦ by apply` construction; it seems to work verbatim without it, i.e. `exact âŸ¨âŸ¨A, openaâŸ©, V, diff, one_mem V, Set.disjoint_of_subset_right hV disjâŸ©` works. You can golf it a bit further by dot-notating on `disj` using `Disjoint.mono_right`, which is a general lemma about lattices which implies `Set.disjoint_of_subset_right`. Finally, I'd suggest different names for the variables (where does `diff` come from?). So my suggestion for this would be
```suggestion
  rcases t2_separation ht with âŸ¨A, B, open_A, open_B, mem_A, mem_B, disjâŸ©
  obtain âŸ¨V, hVâŸ© := is_nonarchimedean B (open_B.mem_nhds mem_B)
  exact âŸ¨âŸ¨A, open_AâŸ©, V, mem_A, one_mem V, disj.mono_right hVâŸ©
```

This lemma doesn't assume that G is a topological group â€“Â it requires a group structure and a topology but no compatibility between them â€“ so it probably shouldn't be in the `TopologicalGroup` namespace.

Moreover, both in this lemma and the next, the topology is actually irrelevant: if you change the type of `V` from `OpenSubgroup G` to `Subgroup G`, and `A` from `Opens G` to `Set G`, to give a purely algebraic statement about subsets of abstract groups, then both lemmas go through with the proofs unchanged. Then you just need to put an `â† OpenSubgroup.coe_toSubgroup` in the `simp_rw` block in `non_singleton_set_disconnected` just before the two lemmas are used.

PS. I just realised that it was your intention to make these lemmas private. Then arguing about whether the proofs make sense more generally isn't relevant any more, so you can probably ignore the above comments.

PPS. But if you want to make them private, then you don't need the additivized version, surely? You use the multiplicative version to prove `non_singleton_set_disconnected`, and then additivize that. The additivization just mechanically applies the multiplicative result to the multiplicativization of an additive group, it doesn't care how the multiplicative result is proved; so to additivize lemma X you don't need to provide additivized versions of all the steps in the proof of X.

golf:
```suggestion
  refine Set.inter_nonempty.mpr âŸ¨y, hy, ?_âŸ©
```

This whole proof can be golfed down to
```
  simpa only [Set.inter_nonempty, Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff y] using
    âŸ¨x, hx, fun con â†¦ Set.not_disjoint_iff.mpr âŸ¨_, con, quotâŸ© dvaâŸ©
```

```suggestion
  obtain âŸ¨u , v, ou, ov, Uuv, Uu, Uv, emptyUuvâŸ© : âˆƒ u v : Set G, IsOpen u âˆ§ IsOpen v âˆ§
      U âŠ† u âˆª v âˆ§ (U âˆ© u).Nonempty âˆ§ (U âˆ© v).Nonempty âˆ§ U âˆ© (u âˆ© v) = âˆ… :=
    âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul y, (V.isClosed.smul y).isOpen_compl, 
      Set.union_compl_self _ â–¸ U.subset_univ, nonempty_intersection_coset hy V, 
      non_empty_intersection_compl_coset hx ha V dav.symm, 
      (Set.inter_compl_self _).symm â–¸ U.inter_emptyâŸ©
  exact fun âŸ¨_, h2âŸ© â†¦ (h2 u v ou ov Uuv Uu Uv).ne_empty emptyUuv
```
Multiple comments here. Firstly, the use of `simp_rw` seems a bit clumsy: your goal is a big chain of "and"s and you are using simp_rw to deal with each of them in turn, so at the end the goal has become `True âˆ§ True âˆ§ True ...`. Hence the search-and-replace facility of `simp_rw` isn't being used, and there's a danger of "leakage" if the rewrites you use for one goal have some effect on the other. So I'd suggest being honest about the fact that you're dealing with the subgoals in turn.

The next natural idea would be to use focussing dots, and a tactic block for each subgoal; but actually every single goal can be made into a one-liner â€“Â Lean's dot-notation is a very powerful weapon here. Note also the use of term-mode rewrites, `foo â–¸ bar` to mean "rewrite using foo in bar".

Finally, in the last line: function composition associates leftwards by default, (((so all the) brackets) aren't required). `emptyUuv <| ((((h2 u v ou) ov) Uuv) Uu) Uv` is parsed exactly the same as `emptyUuv (h2 u v ou ov Uuv Uu Uv)`. I removed some other superfluous brackets as well.
Thank you--these are good to know.

```suggestion
- `NonarchimedeanGroup.instTotallySeparated`:
  A nonarchimedean group is a totally separated topological space.
```
I slightly prefer this formatting.
I don't think this namespace is needed. The lemma can go into the `NonarchimedeanGroup` namespace. (Or you inline it into the instance, as David suggested.)

I think this is already in `docs/references.bib`, so we can write
```suggestion
See Proposition 2.3.9 and Problem 63 in [F. Q. GouvÃªa, *p-adic numbers*][gouvea1997].
```

You can prove a more precise statement here: if `a â‰  b`, then there exists an open subgroup `V` such that `a * V` and `b * V` are disjoint. This should follow from the fact that open subgroups form a basis of nhds of `1`.
I am working on this.

This instance should have reduced priority.
```suggestion
instance (priority := 100) instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: a nonarchimedean group is totally disconnected

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2f3455fa89](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16687/commits/2f3455fa89f0c9b74ddf24b25a847fb6b80fc607)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Algebra.Nonarchimedean.TotallyDisconnected`|993|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ exists_openSubgroup_separating`
`+ instance (priority := 100) instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Many variables in theorems should use implicit variables, as they can be derived from other variables. For example, in `open_subgroup_separating`, it should be `{G : Type*} {t : G}`, in `non_empty_intersection_compl_coset`, it should be `{G : Type*} {x y : G} {U : Set G} (hx : x âˆˆ U) {A : Opens G}`, in `non_empty_intersection_coset`, it should be `{G : Type*} {y : G} {U : Set G}`, and in `non_singleton_set_disconnected`, it should be `{G : Type*} {x y : G} {U : Set G}`.

I only just noticed this PR. It seems several of us (you, me, @pechersky, and possibly more) are thinking along the same lines. To be precise,

- Yakov showed in #17297 (merged) that metric spaces with an ultrametric are totally disco,
- I show in #17262 (awaiting review) that _commutative_ normed groups with an ultrametric norm are nonarchimedean groups,
- you show here that nonarchimedean groups are totally disco.

It seems to me like none of these statements actually imply the other (with the definitions in force in mathlib); and I don't see any obvious way of formulating a more general statement that implies more than one of the above. Still I think it's probably worth us all reading each other's code, and thinking if there's anything in common in the proofs that could profitably be factored out. I'll take a look at your code here later today (I have a long train journey to occupy!)

I spent a while carefully reading this step-by-step as my train rolled through the Alps, and wrote a whole load of very detailed comments.

Ironically, as I was reviewing the very last declaration, I realised that the whole thing can be done a bit differently. The point is that `TotallyDisconnectedSpace` is implied by `TotallySeparatedSpace`, and `TotallySeparatedSpace` is actually **easier** to prove for nonarchimedean groups. So you can just do this straight after `open_subgroup_separating`:
```lean
@[to_additive]
instance instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
  isTotallySeparated_univ x _ y _ hxy := by
    rcases open_subgroup_separating (hxy âˆ˜ inv_mul_eq_one.mp) with âŸ¨A, V, hA, -, hAVâŸ©
    refine âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul x, (V.isClosed.smul x).isOpen_compl, mem_own_leftCoset ..,
        ?_, (Set.union_compl_self _).ge, Set.disjoint_compl_right_iff_subset.mpr (le_refl _)âŸ©
    rw [Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff]
    exact Set.disjoint_left.mp hAV hA
```
This means the other lemmas in this file aren't needed any more for the totally-disconnected proof. Do you have specific reasons for wanting the other lemmas from this file for other downstream PR's? In any case I've left my comments on them here in case you find the general style guidance there useful, even if the code itself doesn't end up getting merged.

Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack. 

I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

```
namespace NonarchimedeanGroup

variable {G : Type*} [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T1Space G]

@[to_additive] instance instTotallySeparated : TotallySeparatedSpace G where
  isTotallySeparated_univ x _ y _ hxy := by
    obtain âŸ¨V, hâŸ© := is_nonarchimedean _ (isOpen_ne.mem_nhds (Ne.symm (inv_mul_eq_one.not.mpr hxy)))
    refine âŸ¨_, _, V.isOpen.smul x, (V.isClosed.smul x).isOpen_compl, mem_own_leftCoset ..,
      ?_, (Set.union_compl_self _).ge, Set.disjoint_compl_right_iff_subset.mpr (le_refl _)âŸ©
    simpa only [Set.mem_compl_iff, mem_leftCoset_iff] using fun a â†¦ h a rfl

example : TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := inferInstance -- works

end NonarchimedeanGroup
```

> Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack.
> 
> I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

Any topological group is a regular space by [TopologicalGroup.regularSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#TopologicalGroup.regularSpace), so if it is a T0 space, then it is a T3 space. Therefore, as long as the version for `T2Space` is proven, the version for `T0Space` can be directly obtained via `inferInstance`.

````lean
local instance (G : Type*) [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T2Space G] :
    TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := sorry

instance (G : Type*) [TopologicalSpace G] [Group G] [NonarchimedeanGroup G] [T0Space G] :
    TotallyDisconnectedSpace G := inferInstance
````

> > Thinking a little further about this: the argument becomes more natural if we assume only that G is T1, not T2, because then the output of the separation axioms gives us exactly what we need, rather than stronger but more complicated information which we have to unpack.
> > I'm not sure if this is actually any more general (it wouldn't surprise me if T1 and T2 are equivalent under our assumptions) (EDIT: yes, they are), but it makes the argument far shorter:

> Any topological group is a regular space by [TopologicalGroup.regularSpace](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Algebra/Group/Basic.html#TopologicalGroup.regularSpace), so if it is a T0 space, then it is a T3 space. 

Glad to hear we have this! What I actually wasn't sure about was whether `NonarchimedeanGroup` implied `TopologicalGroup` â€“ the definition makes perfect sense for a topological space that is also an abstract group; you don't need to assume continuity of the group operations to define it, although it does seem that mathlib has chosen to enforce that G be a topological group nonetheless. (Indeed I suspect that the nonarchimedean property very probably *implies* continuity of the group operations, which would mean two of the arguments to the constructor of `NonarchimedeanGroup` are redundant, but I haven't checked that carefully.)

Thanks very much for reviewing my code! I didn't know about the PRs #17297 and #17262. I wrote this PR and the one you previously reviewed in order to state things concerning representation theory of reductive p-adic groups. I had discussed with Yakov the fact that Mathlib is missing a definition of local fields (I was working around this). Do you have any thoughts about how all of our code might work together?
I tried to rename the file to TotallySeparated.lean, but this failed. How do I do this properly?

> I tried to rename the file to TotallySeparated.lean, but this failed. How do I do this properly?

You need to modify the file names in `Mathlib.lean` as well.
By the way, I think you can mention in the docstring that `TotallyDisconnectedSpace` is implied by `TotallySeparatedSpace`.

> Do you have any thoughts about how all of our code might work together?

I think "very nicely" is the answer :-) There doesn't seem to be any overlap between this and the other two PR's I mentioned, rather they combine together very well (unlike the case with Yakov's PR and mine where there was genuine duplication). It's interesting to hear that you are working towards smooth, admissible, etc reps of LCTD groups, so the "natural example" of G for you is probably GL(2, Qp). It's a beautiful theory, I'm sure you'll have a lot of fun with it. :smile:

As for this PR: I see that you've followed my suggestion to prove "totally separated", and let Lean's typeclass instance machinery deduce "totally disconnected" from that. It's clear that "totally disconnected" will get used more often though, so changing the filename is optional (but Yongle is totally right that the docstring needs updating). 

I did also suggest an alternative layout for the argument (cf comment starting "Thinking a little further about this..."), which shortens things slightly by not having the lemma  `exists_openSubgroup_separating` as a separate declaration, but instead folding it into the proof of the instance. I guess the question is: in your view, is `exists_openSubgroup_separating` only useful as a step towards the totally-separated instance, or might it have other uses beyond the current PR? If it's a one-trick pony, we should fold it into the proof of the instance rather than having a separate lemma. Conversely, if it has other uses, it should have a proper docstring. (Either way is fine with me.)
